text.title: Direct and Indirect Object Pronouns Part 2

sections.title: Agreement with Direct Object Pronouns in Compound Tenses

paragraphs.content: When a **direct object pronoun** is used with a verb in the **present perfect** (or any other compound tense), the **past participle** must agree in gender and number with the pronoun:

rows: **‘Hai invitato Anna e Sara?’ ‘Sì,** ***le*** **ho invitat*****e***.’
‘Did you invite Anna and Sara?’ ‘Yes, I invited them.’
**‘Avete portato i libri?’ ‘Sì,** ***li*** **abbiamo portat*****i***.’
‘Have you brought the books?’ ‘Yes, we’ve brought them.’
**Ho comprato delle rose e** ***le*** **ho dat*****e*** **a Luisa.**
I bought some roses and gave them to Luisa.
**‘Chi ha scritto questa musica?’ ‘*****L’*****ha scritt*****a*** **Bob Marley.’**
‘Who wrote this music?’ ‘Bob Marley wrote it.’
**‘Dove hai comprato quelle scarpe?’** ***‘Le*** **ho comprat*****e*** **al mercato.’**
‘Where did you buy those shoes?’ ‘I bought them at the market.’
**Ho 25 compagni di classe e** ***li*** **ho invitat*****i*** **tutti alla mia festa di compleanno.**
I have 25 classmates and I’ve invited all of them to my birthday party.
**Non** ***ci*** **hanno invitat*****i*** **alla festa.**
They didn’t invite us to the party. [we are all males, or mixed males and females]
**Mauro** ***mi*** **ha accompagnat*****a*** **alla stazione.**
Mauro took me to the station. [the speaker is female]
***Ti*** **hanno invitat*****a?***
Did they invite you? [the person addressed is female]

paragraphs.content: Particular care must be taken when the gender is not shown in the pronoun, as in the last three examples.
Note that when the polite form is used, the past participle always agrees with the feminine pronoun **La**, not with the gender of the person being spoken to:

rows: **Signor Belli, chi L’ha invitat*****a***?
Who invited you, Mr Belli?
**Dottor Ranieri, L’abbiamo vist*****a*** **ieri sera alla televisione.**
We saw you on television last night, Dr Ranieri.

sections.title: No Agreement with Indirect Object Pronouns

paragraphs.content: The rule given above does not apply to *indirect object pronouns*: with these, the past participle of the verb never changes:

rows: **‘Hai telefonato a Anna e Sara?’ ‘Sì,** ***gli*** **ho telefonat*****o***.’
‘Did you phone Anna and Sara?’ ‘Yes, I phoned them.’
**Quando è venuta Livia,** ***le*** **ho offert*****o*** **un gelato.**
When Livia came I offered her an ice cream.
**Ho parlato con Carla** ***e*** **le ho dett*****o*** **tutto.**
I spoke to Carla and told her everything.
**Non** ***ci*** **hanno scritt*****o***.
They didn’t write to us.

sections.title: Object Pronouns with Infinitives in Compound Tenses

paragraphs.content: As we saw in Units 7 and 10, when a direct or indirect object pronoun occurs in a sentence together with a verb in the infinitive (usually after **dovere**, **potere**, **volere** or **sapere**), it can be attached to the **infinitive**.
In these sentences, when the main verb is in the present perfect (or any other compound tense) there is no agreement of the past participle, even with direct object pronouns:

rows: ‘Hai letto tutti i libri?’ ‘Sì, ho dovut***o*** legger***li*** tutti.’
‘Did you read all the books?’ ‘Yes, I had to read all of them.’
Carmen mi ha scritto una lettera, ma non ho ancora potut***o*** legger***la***.
Carmen wrote me a letter, but I still haven’t been able to read it.
Daniela ha molte compagne di scuola, ma non ha volut***o*** invitar***le*** alla festa.
Daniela’s got a lot of school friends, but she didn’t want to/wouldn’t ask them to the party.
‘Avete fatto gli esercizi?’ ‘No, non abbiamo saput***o*** far***li***.’
‘Did you do the exercises?’ ‘No, we couldn’t/didn’t know how to do them.’

paragraphs.content: However, when the **direct object pronoun** is not attached to the **infinitive**, the **past participle** must agree with it:

rows: ‘Hai letto tutti i libri?’ ‘Sì, ***li*** ho dovut***i*** leggere tutti.’
‘Did you read all the books?’ ‘Yes, I had to read all of them.’
Carmen mi ha scritto una lettera, ma non ***l’***ho ancora potut***a*** leggere.
Carmen wrote me a letter but I still haven’t been able to read it.
Daniela ha molte compagne di scuola, ma non ***le*** ha volut***e*** invitare alla festa.
Daniela’s got a lot of school friends, but she didn’t want to/wouldn’t ask them to the party.

paragraphs.content: In contemporary spoken Italian (and sometimes in written Italian as well), agreement of the past participle with first and second person direct object pronouns tends not to be observed; this is the case with both singular (**mi**, **ti**) and plural (**ci**, **vi**), so quite often you will hear (or read) sentences like the following:

rows: ‘Susanna, chi ti ha accompagnato?’
‘Susanna, who went with/took you?’
instead of ti ha accompagnata
‘Mi ha accompagnato Sebastiano.’
‘Sebastiano went with/took me.’
instead of mi ha accompagnata
Ci ha invitato alla festa.
He/She has asked us to the party.
instead of ci ha invitati
Vi ho visto entrare al cinema.
I saw you go into the cinema.
instead of vi ho visti

paragraphs.content: However, the agreement is always made with the third person pronouns (**lo**, **la**, **li**, **le**):

rows: ***L’***ha accompagnat***a*** Sebastiano.
Sebastiano went with/took her.
***Li*** ho invitat***i*** alla festa.
I’ve asked them to the party.
‘Quando hai visto Carla e Livia?’ ‘***Le*** ho vist***e*** ieri.’
‘I saw them yesterday.’

exercises.title: Exercise 1
exercises.instruction: Complete the sentences with the direct object pronouns, making sure that the past participle agrees.
examples: Ho visto Gianna e —— ho invitat—: l’ho invitata

items.question: **Ho comprato** dei fiori e **— ho mess—** in un vaso.
**La zia è partita** e **— ho accompagnat—** alla stazione.
**Ho visto** delle belle scarpe e **— ho comprat—**.
Lara **ha aperto** le finestre, ma Luca **— ha chius—**.
Mi **hanno regalato** dei biscotti e **— ho mangiat—** tutti.
Luisa, **non hai sentito** che Claudio **— ha chiamat—**?
Gaetano **ha preso** il giornale e **— ha lett—**.
‘Vi **hanno invitati** alla festa?’ ‘No, **non — hanno invitat—**.’
‘**Hai preso** i biglietti per il concerto?’ ‘Sì, **— ho pres—**.’
Cerchi i libri? **— ho dat—** a Giovanni.

exercises.title: Exercise 2
exercises.instruction: Complete the sentences with the correct direct or indirect object pronoun, making sure that the past participle agrees where necessary.
examples: Non ho telefonato a Maria, ——— ho scritt—: le ho scritto
Ho comprato una minigonna rossa e —ho indossat— per la festa: l’ho indossata

items.question: Ho incontrato Lina e —— ho offert— un caffè.
Cerco Paola e Gianni, —— avete vist—?
Non ho la bicicletta perché — ho imprestat— a Filippo.
Non ho scritto a Paola, — ho telefonat—.
Dove sono le chiavi? Chi — ha pres—?
Parlo bene l’italiano e il tedesco perché — ho studiat— per sette anni.
Ieri ho visto Alessandro e — ha presentat— sua sorella.
Caterina, chi — ha accompagnat— ieri sera?
Oggi è il compleanno di Daniela, — hai mandat— gli auguri?
Gianna è una vecchia amica: ——ho conosciut— otto anni fa.
‘Dove avete lasciato la bici?’ ‘——abbiamo lasciat— in strada.’
Hai telefonato a Giacomo? Che cosa —— hai dett—?
‘Hai comprato i francobolli?’ ‘Sì, —— ho comprat—.’
Signora, L’ho cercata ieri, ma non ——ho trovat—.
Sebastiano ha molte amiche e io —— ho conosciut— tutte.
‘Cosa hai detto a Matteo?’ ‘Non —— ho dett— nulla.’
‘Chi ha pagato il conto?’ ‘——ha pagat— mia madre.’
‘Cosa hai raccontato a Giulia?’ ‘—— ho raccontat— la verità.’
Professore, chi ——ha accompagnat— in aeroporto?
Questa è una rivista molto interessante: ——ho lett— tutta.

exercises.title: Exercise 3
exercises.instruction: Rewrite the sentences as shown in the example, changing the **pronoun** placement with **modal verbs**.
examples: Ho dovuto comprarle: Le ho dovute comprare.

items.question: Non ho saputo farli.
Ho voluto vederli.
Non abbiamo potuto chiamarlo.
Hanno potuto aiutarvi?
Abbiamo dovuto invitarla.
Non ha saputo tradurle.
Avete dovuto accompagnarle?
Ha voluto mangiarla.
Hai potuto vederli?
Non hanno voluto farle.

exercises.title: Exercise 4
exercises.instruction: Translate the following sentences into Italian, using the **present perfect** tense and appropriate pronouns.
examples: Ho dovuto comprarle: Le ho dovute comprare.

items.question: Sabina hasn’t invited me [f].
Who called you [fs]?
We phoned them yesterday.
I looked for you [mp], but I didn’t find you.
items.answer: Vi ho cercati, ma non vi ho trovati.

items.question: Chiara took us to the bus stop.
items.answer: Chiara ci ha accompagnati alla fermata dell’autobus.

items.question: I sent you [pl.] a postcard – did you receive it?
items.answer: Vi ho mandato una cartolina – l’avete ricevuta?

items.question: My grandparents gave me 100 euros, but I’ve already spent it. [Say: ‘spent them’]
items.answer: I miei nonni mi hanno dato 100 euro, ma li ho già spesi.

items.question: I bought two rolls and ate them.
items.answer: Ho comprato due panini e li ho mangiati.

items.question: ‘Have you [sing.] switched the light off?’ ‘Yes, I’ve switched it off.’
Carla hasn’t been able to help them [f].
items.answer: Carla non le ha potute aiutare.
